results.headline: Review: ‘Beauty and the Beast’ Revels in Joy and Enchantment
results.summary_short: A compassionate Belle and a splendid monster are the hallmarks of this live-action remake of the 1991 animated film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beauty and the Beast

results.headline: Review: In ‘Apprentice,’ Teaching the Fine Art of Execution
results.summary_short: In this film from Singapore, the chief executioner at a high-security prison takes on a new assistant.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Apprentice

results.headline: Review: Reunited, and It Feels So Awkward in ‘Donald Cried’
results.summary_short: In this comedy directed by Kris Avedisian, frenemies from high school rediscover each other for better and worse when one returns to their hometown.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Donald Cried

results.headline: Review: ‘Junction 48’: An Arab Rapper’s Refuge Amid Charged Politics
results.summary_short: In this drama directed by Udi Aloni, Tamer Nafar plays an Arab Israeli citizen trying to build a music career.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Junction 48

results.headline: Review: Sandra Oh and Anne Heche in One Ferocious ‘Catfight’
results.summary_short: In this film that takes jabs at callous privilege, two former college frenemies face off in a battle of trophy wife versus struggling artist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Catfight

results.headline: Review: Shirley MacLaine Wants ‘The Last Word’? She Should Have It
results.summary_short: The 82-year-old actress holds your attention, but this film about a woman padding out her future obituary has an artificial ring.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Word

results.headline: Review: Israel Is the Focus of ‘The Settlers’ and ‘Ben-Gurion: Epilogue’
results.summary_short: Issues of sovereignty in the Middle East are revisited in a pair of documentaries.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Settlers

results.headline: Review: Pursuing (Cyber) Connections in ‘The Human Surge’
results.summary_short: Eduardo Williams’s film blurs the lines between narrative and documentary, adding cryptic observations while navigating Buenos Aires and the Web.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Human Surge

results.headline: Review: It’s All Mirth and Taxes in ‘Love & Taxes’
results.summary_short: Josh Kornbluth runs afoul of the Internal Revenue Service after failing to file tax returns for seven years.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love & Taxes

results.headline: Review: A Father Dies, and Duty Weighs on a Son in ‘Nakom’
results.summary_short: Kelly Daniela Norris and T. W. Pittman’s movie tells the story of a young medical student in Ghana, who returns home to a village to pay off a debt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nakom

results.headline: Review: At ‘Table 19,’ Random Wedding Guests Straining to Laugh
results.summary_short: Slapstick and sap vie for prominence in a comedy so lazy that it actually features someone falling off a log.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Table 19

results.headline: Review: ‘Water & Power: A California Heist,’ With Citizens in the Crossfire
results.summary_short: This documentary from Marina Zenovich outlines a contentious history of state water rights with a scrupulous tenacity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Water & Power: A California Heist

results.headline: Review: A Crisis of Faith and a Trip to God’s B&B in ‘The Shack’
results.summary_short: Sam Worthington and Octavia Spencer star in “The Shack,” a Christian-themed film based on a best seller.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Shack

results.headline: Review: In ‘Logan,’ a Comic-Book Stalwart Turns Noirish Western
results.summary_short: This is old-school meets new-school pulp filled with intimations of mortality, and raw, ugly violence. And once again, Hugh Jackman plays the Wolverine.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Logan

results.headline: Review: ‘Before I Fall,’ a Melodramatic ‘Groundhog Day’
results.summary_short: Zoey Deutch relives a day repeatedly until she gets it right in this film based on a young-adult novel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before I Fall

results.headline: Review: In ‘Wolves,’ a High School Athlete Can’t Outrun Clichés
results.summary_short: Taylor John Smith and Michael Shannon star in a sports film that transcends its stock characters for a while but eventually disappoints.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wolves

results.headline: Review: ‘Kiki’: The Vogueing Scene, Still a Refuge for Gay and Transgender Youth
results.summary_short: There are echoes of “Paris Is Burning” in this documentary, which chronicles a tight-knit community in New York. Yet there is a striking absence of elder mentors.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kiki

results.headline: Review: ‘Contemporary Color,’ David Byrne’s Ode to Color Guards
results.summary_short: An enchantment with these groups comes through in this documentary, which captures music and the backstage buzz of the performers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Contemporary Color

results.headline: Review: In ‘Get Out,’ Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner? (Bad Idea!)
results.summary_short: This movie by Jordan Peele, his first as a director of feature films, is a skillful hybrid, blending genres into something terrifying.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Get Out

results.headline: Review: ‘Les Hautes Solitudes,’ the Silent Sides of Jean Seberg (Mostly)
results.summary_short: This 1974 film by the French director Philippe Garrel consists primarily of studies of young women, especially the actress Seberg.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Les Hautes Solitudes
